column2: Sahidic culture has been present ever since Saint Mark introduced Christianity to Egypt shortly after Christ's ascension. We speak our own language and maintain our own traditions, as we have for centuries. To some, we are the only true Egyptians that remained once the Muslims took over most of North Africa. As I am a Christian myself, perhaps it is time I embrace that distinction from the Arabs around me?

Sahidic culture existed in Egypt long before the Muslim conquest. We speak our own language and maintain our own traditions, as we have for centuries. To some, we are the only true Egyptians that remained once the Muslims took over most of North Africa. Perhaps it is time I embrace that distinction from the Arabs around me?
The Coptic Arabs in [Root.GetName] have slowly begun to adopt the language and traditions of the Sahidic.
While I am in every way Sahidic, I am not Coptic, and it seems pointless to hold onto outdated ways that are so closely tied to the Coptic faith, does it not?
True, I am really an Egyptian
No, I am Sahidic and will remain thus
With the people in [Root.GetName] no longer clinging to the Coptic faith, their Sahidic traditions and language have begun to fall to the wayside.
